head.title: After the Storm, Preparing for More

hedline.hl1: After the Storm, Preparing for More

abstract.p: Martin I Hassner and Judith Mason letters on April 29 editorial on flooding from northeaster and George Hendrey and Stephen Pekar's May 6 Op-Ed article on need to prepare for future climate change

block.p: Re ''Storm Warnings'' (editorial, April 29): The residents of the sound shore communities under water are on top of the socioeconomic spectrum -- especially those here in Rye. Are they so well-to-do that they can easily absorb being flooded out at every serious rainstorm?

Re ''Storm Warnings'' (editorial, April 29): The residents of the sound shore communities under water are on top of the socioeconomic spectrum -- especially those here in Rye. Are they so well-to-do that they can easily absorb being flooded out at every serious rainstorm?

Because they can certainly do the math: tear down all the homes built 50 years ago when the storm sewers were installed and replace them with houses twice the size (and larger) and the storm sewers will flood, manhole covers spewing water or sewage while home drains back up, causing water and sewage to enter homes throughout the area, not just near rampaging brooks.
Only citizen voices can drown out leadership avoidance. Or will it take a sudden real estate slump (who wants to live in places that flood?) to scare up some real action?

George R. Hendrey and Stephen Pekar wrote in ''Local Forecast: Bad'' (Op-Ed, May 6) of the need for an ''international institute'' based in New York where experts ''can put their knowledge together to prepare for future climate change.'' There is also much that individuals and community groups can do to help mitigate some of the disastrous effects of ''climate-driven perils.''

This year, the members of the Long Beach Interfaith Clergy Association have worked to raise awareness within our congregations of the urgent need for emergency preparedness. In the last month, the association has developed a form now being implemented here to identify those in our at-risk city most in need of assistance in the event of a hurricane or other disaster.
Devout individuals from many different religions coming together for such a compassionate service is -- unlike a hurricane -- a genuine ''act of God.''
The writer is outreach director, St. James of Jerusalem Episcopal Church.
